notesStmt.note: [NOTES: it seems that Eilidh Walker’s ‘cattle’ questionnaire was later used to accommodate a list of miscellaneous words provided by Mr Anderson and Mrs MacD. According to the slips and the card index of informants, Mr Anderson is James Anderson of Killin (70s in 1968) and Mrs MacD is Mrs MacDermid of Loch Tay, b. Glenlyon (c. 60 in 1968). In most cases, the list gives only phonetic transcriptions of words but when the questionnaire was slipped, orthography had to be added. Therefore in this file, whenever possible, the orthography has been included as well. Square brackets were added if the spelling used came from a different source than the slips themselves (usually Dwelly). Additional information found on the slips has been also included, as well as any differences between the information provided by the questionnaire and the slips, such as differences in orthography.]

person.persName: identified as Mr Anderson, Killin and Mrs MacD

body.head: 1. Different stages in the growth of cattle

form.pron: [NOTES: both slipped under ‘laogh’ with ‘a. laogh firionn’ and ‘b. laogh boirionn’ as the quotation. Definition: a. male calf; b. female calf.]

entry.def: [NOTES: both slipped under ‘laogh’ with ‘a. laogh firionn’ and ‘b. laogh boirionn’ as the quotation. Definition: a. male calf; b. female calf.]
dehorned or hornless cow. [NOTES: slip not found.]

Sean-Fhacal Gaidhlig: An deigh oidhche Shamhan their iad crodh ris na h’aighean agus aighean ris na laoigh. [NOTES: slipped under ‘Samhuinn’. The quotation has ‘Oidhche Shamhuin’ [sic] and ‘ris na h-aighean’.]

body.head: Mr Anderson, Killin

entry.def: [du̜ r[ou]] mole. [NOTES: the slip has [du̜ˈ rɔu].]
[dʹəɫəman dʹɛ̜:] butterfly. [NOTES: slipped under ‘dealman-dé’. No pronunciation.]
[ʃɛ̜lʹ[ɑi]n] smaller than bumble. [NOTES: the slip has [ruˈa]. Definition: A bee smaller than the bumble bee but wasp like in its sting.]

[ʃɛ̜:liçək] snail. Chunnaic mi seilcheag air an lice lom; chual mi chuthag gam miar mo bhroinn; chunnaic mi an t-searrach ’s a chùlaobh rium, is dh’aithnich mi nach robh bhliadhn’ dol leam. [NOTES: the saying was slipped under the catch-word ‘seilcheag’ so it has been placed here. The slip gives only the phonetic transcription of the word spelled ‘miar’ in the questionnaire: [iər].]
[ʃɛ̜lax] willow. [NOTES: the slip has [ʃɛ̜ɫəx]. It gives Mrs MacDermid as the source.]
[[ɑu]rnʹɑk] sloe. [NOTES: slipped under ‘abhrneag’ but then ‘airneag’ added in second hand. Pronunciation: [ɑurnʹak].]
car. [NOTES: slipped under ‘carbad-ola’ with ‘carbad-òla’ as the quotation. Definition: Motor car.]
[ən jɑrɑp] roe deer. [NOTES: the slip has [ən jarɑp].]
[du̟ɡan] pole cat. (croit an dugain [?]) [SLIP: Pole cat. Also found in place-name ‘Croftintygane’ near Lawers, Loch Tay.]

form.pron: [NOTES: slipped under Cill-linne. Quotation: (a) Cill-linne. (b) Cillbhinn. Definition: (a) What natives called Killin in informant’s youth (circa 60-70 years ago). (b) Found nowadays.]

entry.def: [NOTES: slipped under Cill-linne. Quotation: (a) Cill-linne. (b) Cillbhinn. Definition: (a) What natives called Killin in informant’s youth (circa 60-70 years ago). (b) Found nowadays.]
[mɛ̜:ran nən dɤnʹə ʃi:iç] foxglove (nickname). [NOTES: the slip has [mɛ̜:raṉ ṉəṉ dɤnʹə ʃiˈiç]. Definition: Foxglove. (‘The thimble of the fairy people’).]

form.pron: [SLIP: Foxglove. Cf. also ‘Meuran nan Daoine Sithich’.]

entry.def: [SLIP: Foxglove. Cf. also ‘Meuran nan Daoine Sithich’.]
[ən d-ˈ[ãũ]n rɔnɡ vɔ:r] daddy-long-legs. [NOTES: the slip has [ən dˈ[ãũ]n rɔŋ vɔ:r].]
[da̜:ɫ] beetle. [NOTES: originally slipped under ‘dàil’ but then ‘daol’ added in second hand.]
fox’s crest (fern). [SLIP: Fox’s crest (a type of fern – English name uncertain).]

body.head: And

entry.def: [li:ən] Glenlyon. [NOTES: the slip has [lʹi:ən]. It gives Mrs MacDermid as the source.]
[dɔxərst] Dochart. [NOTES: phonetic transcription added on the slip.]
Bridge of Balgy. [SLIP: Bridge of Balgie, Glenlyon.]
flat land beside river. [NOTES: slip not found.]
side of mountain. [NOTES: slip not found.]
Ardchyl. [NOTES: slipped under Ard Choill’. Definition: Ardchyl (near Killin).]
[kylɑk] copse. [NOTES: the slip has [kɤlak]. Definition: small group of trees.]
[ɡʹaɫəvɑn] death lights. [SLIP: the slip has [ɡʹaɫəvaṉ]. Definition: Death light.]

body.head: Mrs MacD

entry.def: [kaʃərt] for bròg ’s stòcainn, footwear. [SLIP: Footwear (refers to both shoe and stocking).]
[krasəɫəx] [SLIP: Used of animals, meaning ‘very thin’, ‘only bone to them’.]
[kəɫ ən jariç] [NOTES: slipped under ‘caol’ and ‘earrach’ with ‘caol an earraich’ as the quotation. Definition: Of animals, meaning ‘very thin’.]
[lʹɛsəx] changing milk into cheese (earning). Tha mi dol a dheanamh leasach an diugh.
[mu̜ˈi] churn. Tha muigh ri dheanamh an diugh. [NOTES: slipped under ‘muidhe’.]

[klax jɛ̜riç] whetting stone. [NOTES: there are two slips giving Mrs MacDermid as the source and ‘whetting-stone’ as the definition – one has ‘clach-ghearraich [jɛ̜riç]’ as the catch-word and the other ‘clach-gheuraidh [jɛ̜:ri]’.]
[sra:ər] pad on back of work-horse, saddle. [SLIP: pannier-saddle on work-horse.]

[dʹɛ̜̃ˈwiʃ] [SLIP: shears, N.B. pron.] [NOTES: there is another slip with ‘deimhis’ as the catch-word, Mrs MacDermid as the source and ‘shears’ as the definition but it gives different pronunciation - [dʒɑ̃ũˈis].]
[brɤiɫiç] noise. Nach b’ e sin a’ bhraoilich airson aon adhaircean muic. [NOTES: the slip has [brɤiḻiç]. The quotation has ‘uircean’ instead of ‘adhaircean’.]
[u̟irkʹən] young pig. [NOTES: the quotation on the slip reads ‘uircean muic (or alone)’.]
[sɡɔˈdɑɫ] proud man. [NOTES: slipped under ‘sgodail’ with ‘fear sgodail’ as the quotation. Pronunciation: [sɡɔdal].]
happy man. [NOTES: slipped under ‘sunndach’ with ‘duine sunndach’ as the quotation. Definition: Happy.]
B’ e cearnach e ’na latha. – He was a big man (stature) in his day.
a big man (stature). [NOTES: the slip gives a quotation ‘B’ e famhair e ‘na latha’. Definition: ‘A big man (in stature)’.]

body.head: Mrs MacD

entry.def: [pɛ̜liʃtʹər] like 9 pins – one big one you threw small ones at it to knock it down. [SLIP: A game. Similar to 9 pins. A big stone is placed on its side and smaller stones thrown to knock it down.]
[əm vu̜axk] cold. [NOTES: slipped under ‘fuachd’ with ‘am fuachd’ as the quotation. Definition: N.B. pron. – the cold (illness).]
[bu̜ləɡər bɑɫiç] rascal. ’Se am [bu̜ləɡər]. [NOTES: slipped under ‘builgear’. Pronunciation: [bu̜ɫəɡər baɫiç].]
[sɡlɔk sən lʹɛ̜:çən] slap on jaw. [NOTES: slipped under ‘sglog’ with ‘sglog ‘san lethcheann’ as the quotation. Definition: Slap on the jaw. Separate slip for ‘lethcheann’ – jaw.]
[ɡrɑmɑil] [sic] firm, stern. [NOTES: the slip does not give the pronunciation.]
[ɡiməlidʹ] iron-pointed tool for cobbler. [NOTES: the slip has [ɡiməɫɛdʹ]. Definition: For taking tackets out of boots.]
[saɡɑrstʹ] last for boots. [NOTES: the slip has [sakɑrstʹ]. Definition: Cobbler’s last for boots.]
[pɑlʹart] good, firm slap. [NOTES: the slip has [palʹart].]
[k[oi]lərən] candle-sticks. [NOTES: slipped under ‘coinnleir’ with ‘pl. [k[(õ)(ĩ)]ḻərən]’ as the quotation.]
[ɡlɑkərəxk] gossip. Bha iad a’ glagaireachd fad an latha. [NOTES: the slip has [ɡɫakərəxk]. Definition: Gossip. (Also fem. noun).]
[kɑp] mouth (of fish; of human – mouth). Dùin do chap! [sic] [SLIP: Mouth (of fish or, as above [i.e. in the quotation], in insult, of human).]
[dʹɛ̜səx] bake. Bheil an deasach deas? [SLIP: Baking.]
Tha e coltach ri fear a tha air caitheamh seachd colann [kɑi ʃɛxk kɔɫən]. – of old person. [SLIP: Said of a decrepit-looking old person.]
barrel of tar. [NOTES: slipped under ‘togsaid’ with ‘togsaid theàrr’ as the quotation.]
Bheil thu ’tuigsinn, [aɫ̱iç]? - like ‘laochain’, from man to man. [NOTES: definition on the slip: Like ‘a laochain’ etc., used from man to man. Prob. shortened form of ‘a bhalaich’.]
[klaxˈ vaɫak] blowhard. [NOTES: the slip has [kɫaxˈ vaɫax].]
best man. [NOTES: slipped under ‘fleasgach’. Definition: Possibly ‘leasgach’ (i.e. without f-) used. ‘Best man’.]

body.head: Mrs MacD

entry.def: [dʹɛ̜ʃər] people of north [sic] side of Loch Tay. [NOTES: slipped under ‘deisir’ with ‘muinntir deisir’ as the quotation. Definition: People belonging to north side of Loch Tay. (cf. also tuatharach).]

[tu̜ərəx] people of south [sic] side of Loch Tay. [NOTES: slipped under ‘tuatharach’ with ‘muinntir tuatharach’ as the quotation. Definition: People belonging to south side of Loch Tay. (cf. also ‘deisir’) Saying of informant’s mother: ‘Bodaichean tuatharach, is tuath Gleann Dochairt, Mionnasgan Chillfhinn agus daoine grinn na Sràid Ghlais (in Killin) Barran Gleann Lòcha agus brod deisir [sic].’]
[kʹɛʰpər] good sustaining piece, sandwich. [SLIP: A big sandwich.]
[u̟tərmɑn] pig’s bladder. [NOTES: the slip has [u̟t̪ərman]. Definition: Pig’s bladder. N. B. pron.]
[sɡɔnərəx] clumsy person. Bha sgonnarach mun cuairt. [SLIP: clumsy person, cf. ‘sgonn’.]
[sɡu̜[ɑi]ʃ] something done in hurried way and unthorough. Bha sguais uamharaidh aige. [SLIP: Something done in a hurried, and consequently unthorough, way.]
[klɛ̜ʰtʹərstiç] flapping and fussing. Bha i cleiteartaich mun cuairt.
deer fat. [NOTES: all four above slipped together under ‘geir’.]

[mulaxɑk] geir feidh [sic] [deer fat] in a mould (endowed with healing powers – any wound or baby’s navel). [NOTES: slipped under ‘mulchag’ with ‘mulchag geir feidh’ as the quotation. Definition: Deer fat in a mould. Endowed with healing properties – for a wound or was rubbed on a baby’s navel.]

body.head: [Eilidh Walker]
2. Breeds of cattle
3. Outward appearance of cattle
4. Names for certain beasts, e.g. an animal on which the owner bestows particular attention
5. Parts of the body

entry.def: [pron.] head. [NOTES: there is a slip with ‘ceann’ as the catch-word and Ellie Walker as the source but it gives a phrase - Ceann mór aig duine glic, Ceann circ air amadan.]
forehead. [NOTES: slipped under ‘clàr-aodann’. Definition: Forehead (of cow).] [NOTES: the spelling on the slip – clàr-aodann.]
horns. [NOTES: slipped under ‘adharc’ with ‘pl. [[œi]rçkən]’ as the quotation but there is a wavy line in pencil going across the latter possibly to show that the transcription may be wrong.]
hair. [NOTES: ‘beast’ added in second hand (most probably the fieldworker).] [SLIP: Beast’s hair.]
[pron.] hide. [NOTES: [ai] under ‘ai’ in ‘craicean’ added in second hand (most probably the fieldworker).] [NOTES: slip not found.]
[pron.] breast. [NOTES: ‘flappy part on sheep’ added in second hand (most probably the fieldworker).] [NOTES: slipped under ‘caisean-uchd’. Definition: Breast; flappy part on sheep.]
[pron.] hindquarter. [NOTES: slipped under ‘spàg’. Definition: Hindquarter of cow.]
[pron.] rump. [NOTES: slipped under ‘rùmball’. Pronunciation: [ruˈmbəɫ]. Definition: Rump of cattle.]
[pron.] udder. [NOTES: the slip gives the pronunciation – [uʰ].]
[pron.] vein. [NOTES: both ‘feith’ and ‘feath’ slipped under ‘fèith’. Definition: Muscle (cattle). Also: vein.]
blood. [NOTES: the slip gives the pronunciation – [fu̟lʹə].]
glands. [NOTES: slipped under ‘faireag’. Pronunciation: [fɑˈrɑk]. Definition: Gland (partic. in meat).]

body.head: 6. Calving
7. Milking

entry.def: [mɛ̜:s] basin. [NOTES: phonetic transcription added most probably by the fieldworker.] [NOTES: slip not found.]
stool. [NOTES: grave accent added most probably by the fieldworker.] [NOTES: slip not found but see ‘creaban’ below.]
[pron.] stool. [NOTES: slipped under ‘cneaban’. Pronunciation: [krɛ̜̃pan]. Definition: Stool. ‘Stòl’ also used.]
leg-rope. [NOTES: ‘heard “dung”’ added in second hand (most probably the fieldworker).] [SLIP: Leg-rope for cow. Once heard used for ‘dung’. Also fetter for milking.]
morning milking. [NOTES: slipped under ‘bleoghainn-maidne’ with ‘also: bleoghainn-feasgair’ as the quotation.]
[lʹɛ̜səx] calf’s bladder (used for making cheese). [NOTES: the last item added in second hand but the slip still gives Eilidh Walker as the source.] [NOTES: the slip has [lʹesəx].]

body.head: 8. Feeding

entry.def: [pron.] bochtchal) [bɔtʹaɫ] hay or straw in a tidy bundle. [NOTES: phonetic transcription added most probably by the fieldworker. The slip gives [bɔʰtʹaɫ]. Definition: Hay or straw trussed up in a tidy bundle.]

body.head: 9. Apparatus

entry.def: [pron.] weight tied to an animal. [NOTES: the slip gives pronunciation – [kɫɔk].]
calfskin stuffed. [SLIP: Stuffed calfskin – so called because was stuffed with rushes, straw being too valuable.]

body.head: 10. Diseases

entry.def: [pron.] diarrhoea. [NOTES: ‘animals’ added in second hand (most probably the fieldworker). Slipped under ‘sgùr’ with ‘an sgùr’ as the quotation. Definition: Diarrhoea in animals.]
hard udder at calving (mastitis). [NOTES: slipped under ‘ruaidh’ with ‘an ruaidh’ as the quotation.]
ticks. [NOTES: slipped under ‘partan’ with ‘pl. partain’ as the quotation.]

[pron.] cloy) [kɫ[ɔ̃i]] itch. [NOTES: the following added in second hand (most probably the fieldworker) – (partic. sheep scab; also ‘Bheil clòimh ort?’) – funny [?].] [NOTES: phonetic transcription added most probably by the fieldworker.] [SLIP: Itch – particularly of sheep but used jokingly for humans (as above [i.e. in the quotation]).]

body.head: 11. Miscellaneous

entry.def: [pron.] prooee) [prui] call to cow. [NOTES: phonetic transcription added most probably by the fieldworker. The slip has [pruˈi].]
[pron.] call to calf. [NOTES: the slip gives the pronunciation: [pruiˈɛ̜:].]
[call to a] horse (to come to you). [NOTES: the slip has [prɔˈki].]

[vai:n] [calls to horse used when] ploughing, to go one way (furrow) and then the other (rig). Not know which. [NOTES: slipped under [v[ai]:n]. Definition: one of the calls (the other being [həp]) to a horse when ploughing, to tell it to go to furrow or rig. Not known which is which.]
